page.title: 17FOLK CUSTOMS.
page.content: Many churches and Sunday schools hold processions of witness (Walking Days) through the central streets after Whit- suntide. It is the custom for relatives and friends of children who walk, to give them small amounts of money. The young girls often wear long white dresses and banners are carried by church members. Adlington, Coppull and Chorley have annual carnivals with decorated floats, fancy dress parades and carnival Queens and Princesses. Brass bands supply the music and there are Morris dancing competions. Workers about to get married are often made to wear fancy costume and slogans and are 'imprisoned' for a short period by their colleagues in a public place, causing great amusement to passers by. Summer holidays are still called Wakes, a reminder of the cotton towns holidays
